text: Nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS) is an inherited disease transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait with full penetrance and variable expressivity. Mandibular cysts and sickle cerebri calcification were the most frequently observed abnormalities, followed by CB and Palmar / plantar fossae. Like the case of African Americans, the relatively low frequency of CB in the Italian population is probably due to the protective pigmentation of the skin. A future search based on the screening of the mutation could establish a possible genotype-phenotype correlation in Italian patients.

text: Angelica syndrome (AD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by the absence of a maternal contribution to chromosome 15q11-q13. There are four classes of AS according to molecular or cytogenetic status: 15q11-q13 maternal microdeletion (approximately 70% of patients); uniparental uniparental (UPD); defects in an alleged print center (IM); the fourth includes 20-30% of individuals with biparental inheritance and a normal allelic methylation pattern in 15q11-q13. Mutations of UBE3A have recently been identified as causing this latter group. Few studies have investigated phenotypic differences between these classes. Twenty non-deletions were compared to 20 patients with age deletion and significant phenotypic differences were found between both groups. The most severe phenotype in the deletion group may suggest a contiguous gene syndrome.

text: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angel syndrome (EA) are different neurobehavioral disorders that most often originate from a 4 MB deletion of chromosome 15q11-q13 during paternal or maternal gametogenesis, respectively. At a de novo frequency of approximately 67-1 / 10,000 deliveries, these deletions represent a common structural change of the chromosome in the human genome. To elucidate the mechanism underlying these events, regions containing two groups of proximal cut points and one distal cluster have been characterized. Novel DNA sequences potentially associated with cutpoints were positionally cloned from YACs within or near these regions. Analysis of rodent somatic cell hybrids, YAC contigs, and fish from normal or rearranged chromosomes 15 identified duplicate sequences (the final repeats) at or near the cut-off points. The final repeat units are derived from large genomic duplications of a new gene (HERC2), many copies of which are transcriptionally active in germ tissues. One of the five PWS / AS patients analyzed to date has an identifiable and rearranged HERC2 transcript derived from the deletion event. The end is postulated to repeat the 15q11-q13 flank by mediating homologous recombination resulting in deletion. Furthermore, we propose that active transcription of these repeats in male and female germ cells can facilitate the process of homologous recombination.

text: The clinical features of Angelica syndrome (AD) include severe mental retardation, postnatal microcephaly, macrostomy and prognathia, absence of speech, ataxia, and happy disposition. We present seven patients who lack most of these characteristics, but who have obesity, muscle hypotonia and mild mental retardation. Based on these latter findings, the patients were initially suspected of suffering from Prader-Willi syndrome. DNA methylation analysis of SNRPN and D15S63, however, revealed a pattern of AS, i.e. the maternal band was weak or absent. Cytogenetic studies and microsatellite analysis showed apparently normal chromosomes 15 of biparental inheritance. We conclude that these patients have an imprint defect and a previously unrecognized form of AS. The mild phenotype can be explained by an incomplete printing defect or by cellular mosaicism.

text: Pterygium popliteal syndrome (PPS) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder, believed to occur with an incidence of approximately 1 in 300,000 live births. The main clinical manifestations are popliteal, cleft lip, palatal fissure, fossa of the lower lip, syndactyly, and genital and nail abnormalities. PPS has some features in common with van der Woude syndrome (VWS), which is also inherited as an autosomal dominant condition, with cleft lip / palate and, more distinctively, lower lip pits. Although the VWS gene has not yet been identified, it has been localized to within 1.6 cM in the 1q32-41 region. To determine whether PPS and VWS represent allelic forms of the same gene, three families were genotypic for markers flanking and within the critical region. A multipoint LOD score of 2.7 was obtained, with no evidence of recombination, supporting the hypothesis that these two disorders are allelic.

text: Schwanomas of the skin are frequently seen in patients with neurofibromatosis 2. In about a quarter of cases, skin tumors are the first clinical symptoms of this disease. Recognition of skin tumors related to neurofibromatosis-2 is therefore important for the early diagnosis of neurofibromatosis 2, especially in pediatric patients. In this study we examined 40 skin tumors (36 schwannomas and 4 neurofibromas) of 20 neurofibromatosis 2 patients for NF2 mutations and allelic loss. NF2 mutations have been identified in the blood of 15 (75%) of the 20 patients. We found NF2 mutations in five (13%) and loss of NF2 allelic in 18 (45%) of the 40 tumors analyzed. Genetic alterations (allelic loss or mutation) were found in 50 (63%) of the total of 80 alleles examined. Alterations were found in both NF2 alleles in 17 (43%). These results suggest that, as in the case of vestibular schwanomas and meningiomas, the loss of the functional product of the NF2 gene is also the critical event in the development of cutaneous schwanomas. Identifying the genetic alterations of the NF2 gene in skin tumors can help to identify skin tumors associated with neurofibromatosis-2, aiding in the diagnosis of neurofibromatosis 2 in ambiguous cases and excluding neurofibromatosis 1 in unclear cases. We also report that the detection rate of constitutional mutations was higher in patients with skin tumors (65%) than in patients without skin tumors (40%).

text: Regulatory interferon factor 6 (IRF6) belongs to a family of nine transcription factors that share a highly conserved helix-gyro-helix binding domain and a less conserved protein binding domain. Most IRFs regulate the expression of interferon alpha and beta after viral infection, but the function of IRF6 is unknown. The gene encoding of IRF6 is located in the critical region of the van der Woude syndrome (VWS; OMIM 119300) locus on chromosome 1q32-q41 (ref 2, 3). The disorder is an autosomal dominant form of cleft lip and cleft palate with lip pits, and is the most common syndromic form of cleft lip or cleft palate. Pterygium popliteal syndrome (PPS; OMIM 119500) is a disorder with a similar orofacial phenotype that also includes skin and genital abnormalities. text: Mutations in the UBE3A gene (the E6-AP ligase ubiquitin protein gene) have been found in many patients with Angelica syndrome (AS) without deletion, uniparental uniparental, and no printing defect. UBE3A mutations are more frequent in familial patients than in sporadic patients, and the mutations described so far seem to cause similar phenotypes in affected familial cases. Here we describe two cousins that have inherited the same UBE3A frameshift mutation (duplication of ARCAda in exon 10) from their asymptomatic mothers, but have discordant phenotypes. The proband shows typical characteristics. Her affected cousin has a more severe phenotype, with asymmetric spasticity that initially led to the diagnosis of cerebral palsy. Proband's brain MRI shows mild cerebral atrophy while his cousin's MRI of the brain shows severe brain malformations. This family shows that, although the cerebral malformation is unusual in it, the presence of a cerebral malformation does not exclude the diagnosis of AS. Furthermore, this UBE3A mutation was transmitted from the cousin's grandfather to only two sisters among the eight brothers, increasing the mosaic hypothesis for this mutation.

text: Neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2) is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by tumors in the vestibular branch of the VIII cranial nerve, but it also occurs with other types of tumors of the nervous system. Genotype-phenotype correlations are well documented for the overall severity of NF2 disease, but have not been definitively evaluated for specific types of non-VIII nerve tumors. Genotype-phenotype correlations for various types of non-VIII nerve tumors were evaluated in 406 patients in the UK population-based NF2 registry using regression models with additional covariates for current age and type of treatment center ( specialty or non-specialty). The models also allowed for consideration of intra-family correlation. Statistically significant genotype-phenotype correlations were found for meningiomas, spinal tumors, and intracranial peripheral nerve tumors. People with constitutional NF2 mutations, junction point mutations, large deletions, or somatic mosaicism had significantly fewer tumors than people with senseless constitutional mutations or NF2 frameshift. In addition, significant intrafamilial correlations were observed in meningiomas and intracranial spinal tumors, after adjusting for the constitutional NF2 mutation type. The constitutional NF2 mutation type is an important determinant of the number of NF2-associated endocranial meningiomas, spinal tumors, and peripheral nerve tumors.

text: Angelica syndrome is a neurogenetic disorder caused by loss of function of the UBE3A gene printed in 15q11-q13. The presence of a weak maternal band detected by SNURF-SNRPN locus-specific methylation-specific PCR analysis in approximately one-third of patients who have an ID but no deletion from the print center suggested that these patients are ID cell mosaics and normal cells. In two studied patients, somatic mosaicism was demonstrated by molecular and cellular cloning, respectively. X-inactivation studies of cloned fibroblasts from one patient suggest that ID occurred before the blastocyst phase. To quantify the degree of mosaicism, a new quantitative methylation assay was developed based on real-time PCR. In 24 analyzed patients, the percentage of normal cells ranged from <1% to 40%. Regression analysis suggests that patients with a higher percentage of normally denatured cells tend to have milder clinical symptoms than patients with a lower percentage. In conclusion, we suggest that the role of mosaic print defects in mental retardation is undervalued.

text: Heterozygous mutations in the serine threonine kinase receptor BMPR1B typically result in brachydactyly type a2 (BDA2), whereas mutations in the corresponding GDF5 ligand cause brachydactyly type C (BDC). Functional investigations of the R486Q mutation were performed and compared to the BDA2 R486W and WT BMPR1B mutation. Overexpression of the mutant receptors in chicken micromase cultures produced a marked inhibition of chondrogenesis with the R486Q mutant, showing a more intense effect than the R486W mutant. To investigate the consequences of BMPR1B mutations on intracellular signal transduction, stable transfected C2C12 cells were used and the activity of SMAD-dependent and SMAD-independent pathways was measured. SMAD activation after stimulation with GDF5 was suppressed in both mutants. Alkaline phosphatase induction showed almost complete loss of activation by both mutants. text: Mutations in SALL1 and GLI3 are responsible for human limb malformation syndromes. The molecular pathophysiology of these mutations is incompletely understood, and many conclusions have been drawn from studies in the mouse. We identified truncating mutations in SALL1 and GLI3 in patients with limb malformation and studied the contribution of nonsense caries (NMD) to the expression of mutant mRNA in fibroblasts derived from the patient. Quantification of the relative proportions of mutant and wild-type alleles was performed by pyrosequencing. In SALL1, one mutant allele that caused Towne-Brock syndrome was unexpectedly resistant to NMD, while a different mutation that caused a much milder phenotype was susceptible to NMD. In GLI3, all three mutant alleles evaluated were susceptible to NMD. text: The application of recombinant DNA techniques has identified two fundamental mechanisms of tumorigenesis in man. The first involves a qualitative or quantitative change in an oncogene (see Ref. 1 for review). In the second, discovered in embryonal tumors, a primary mutation occurs that is recessive at the cellular level to the normal allele. The growth of a tumor occurs only after a secondary change, such as chromosomal loss or mitotic recombination, eliminates the normal allele, thereby unmasking the altered allele. Because its effect is recessive, the primary mutation can also occur and be transmitted in the germinal tract, resulting in a familiar pattern for the disease. In familial cases, independent bilateral tumors are common, since tumors result from a single event - loss of normal genes - that can occur in any cell. This is in contrast to unfamiliar (sporadic) cases in which solitary tumors result from the infrequent occurrence of two rare events within the same cell. Using a molecular genetic approach, we have shown that acoustic neuroma, one of the most common tumors of the human nervous system, is specifically associated with the loss of genes on human chromosome 22 and may be a consequence of the mechanism of tumorigenesis discovered in embryonic tumors. This finding could provide a clue to the chromosomal location of the defective gene in bilateral acoustic neurofibromatosis, an autosomal dominant disorder with the hallmark of bilateral acoustic neuromas. In view of the frequent occurrence of meningiomas in patients with bilateral acoustic neurofibromatosis and the Association of meningioma with loss of chromosome 22 previously described in cytogenetic studies, we suggest that a common event underlies tumorigenesis in acoustic neuroma and meningioma.

Of the total of 41 tumors, 12.5% were small acoustic neurinomas. In general, tumors were larger at the time of diagnosis in women than in men. A family of three generations is described in which the craniofacial manifestations were prominent and it was considered that the most probable diagnosis was Goldenhar. However, with the recent birth of an affected male with an imperforate anus, the diagnosis of TBS was also considered. The family reports a variety of Goldenhar findings, including epibulbar dermoids, hemifacial microsomy, preauricular tags, macrostomy, and micrognathia, in addition to classic TBS ear, radial, and anal findings. We report this family to point out a possible biological relationship between these two conditions.

text: We present the case of an 8-year-old African American boy with medulloblastoma and nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS) who presented the radiosensitive response of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) formation in the irradiated area for medulloblastoma. This response is well documented in Caucasian NBCCS patients with medulloblastoma. Medulloblastoma was diagnosed at 2 years of age and surgery, chemotherapy, and craniospinal irradiation were performed. At 6 years of age, he was diagnosed with NBCCS after presentation with a large odontogenic keratocyst of the jaw, pits of the palms and soles, and numerous CBs in the back and neck area that had previously been irradiated for medulloblastoma. Examination of other family members showed that Proposition's mother also had NBCCS, but was more mildly affected; in particular, not CB. This case illustrates the complex gene-environment interaction, since increased skin pigmentation in African Americans is presumably protective against ultraviolet radiation, but not ionizing. This case and other similar cases in the literature show the importance of considering NBCCS in the differential diagnosis of any patient presenting with a medulloblastoma, especially before 5 years of age, and of examining other close relatives for signs of NBCCS to determine the patient's risk status. Finally, for individuals who are radiosensitive, protocols that use chemotherapy instead of radiation therapy should be considered.

Both Prader-Willi and Angelan syndrome can also occur as a result of both members of chromosome 15 being derived from one parent, a condition known as uniparental uniparental. Also, Angelica syndrome can be caused by a mutation in the gene that causes it; a comparable cause is not present in Prader-Willi syndrome, as it results from abnormality in more than one gene. Causal mutations have been identified in 54 (43%) classic families and six (35%) of those who met modified criteria. 42 cases from 38 families with truncated mutations had a mean age of onset of symptoms of 19 years and diagnosis at 22.4 years. 51 cases from 16 families with splice site mutations (15 out of six), nonsense mutations (18 out of six), and large deletions (18 out of five) had a mean age of onset of 27.8 years and a diagnosis of 33 ,4 years. Subjects with truncated mutations were significantly more likely to develop symptoms before 20 years of age (p <0.001) and to develop at least two symptomatic CNS tumors, in addition to vestibular schwanoma before age 30 (p <0.001). There were also fewer multigenerational families with truncating mutations. Four truncating mutations were mosaic-shaped and were associated with milder disease than with other similar mutations. This large study has confirmed the prior impression that truncating mutations are associated with severe disease, but caution should be exercised when using the type of mutation to predict the course of disease.

text: Ubiquitin ligase-AP (Human / Mouse gene UBE3A / Ube3a) promotes the degradation of p53 in association with the papilloma protein E6, and maternal deficiency causes human angel syndrome (AD). Ube3a is imprinted with paternal allele silencing in the hippocampus and cerebellum in mice. We found that the phenotype of mice with maternal deficiency (m- / p +) for Ube3a resembles that of humans as with motor dysfunction, inducible seizures, and context-dependent learning deficits. Long-term potentiation (LTP) was severely impaired in m- / p + mice despite normal basal synaptic transmission and neuroanatomy, indicating that ubiquitin may play a role in mammalian LTP and that LTP may be abnormal in AS. The cytoplasmic abundance of p53 was increased in the postmitotic neurons in the m- / p + mice and in AS, providing a potential biochemical basis for the phenotype through the inability to ubiquitinater and degrade some effects.

This is the fourth case of a 15q15q translocation with uniparental paternal uniparental (UPD). Our findings suggest that some patients with clinical features of AS have hyperphagia and obesity with overgrowth, and that these features should not rule out a diagnosis of AS.

text: Patients who present with unilateral vestibular schwannomas, either at an early age or with additional features of type 2 neurofibromatosis (NF2), are at risk of developing bilateral disease and transmitting a risk of neurogenic tumors to their children. Fifteen patients out of a series of 537 have been identified with unilateral vestibular schwanomas who also had one or more of the following tumors (10/15), NF2 features (3/15), or a family history of neurogenic tumors (5/15). No germline NF2 mutations were detected and in 7/9 cases where tumor material was available for analysis, a germline mutation in the NF2 gene was excluded. Although there is still a possibility of gonosomal mosaicism, exclusion tests for offspring are now possible. We suggest a general strategy, based on tumor DNA analysis, to distinguish sporadic and familial cases of tumors caused by two striking mechanisms. The application of this strategy suggests that the majority of unilateral vestibular schwanoma cases that do not meet NF2 criteria represent casual occurrences.

text: Mutations of the human patched gene (PTCH) have been identified in individuals with nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS), as well as sporadic basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma. A homologue of this tumor suppressor gene has been isolated and located on the short arm of chromosome 1 (1P 32.1-32.3). Patch 2 (PTCH2) consists of 22 coding exons and spans approximately 15 KB of genomic DNA. The gene encodes a 1203 amino acid transmembrane protein that is highly homologous to the PTCH product. We have characterized the genomic structure of PTCH2 and used a single-chain conformational polymorphism analysis to look for mutations in PTCH2 in NBCCS patients, basal cell carcinomas, and medulloblastoma. To date, we have identified a truncating mutation in a medulloblastoma and a change in a splice donor site in a basal cell carcinoma, suggesting that the gene plays a role in the development of some tumors.

text: Low copy repeat elements are associated with tiebreaker regions of common deletions in Prader-Willi and Angelan syndromes. We describe here the identification of the ancestral gene (HERC2) and a family of duplicate truncated copies that make up these low-copy repeats. This gene encodes a highly conserved giant protein, HERC2, which is remotely related to P532 (HERC1), a guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) involved in gallbladder traffic. The mouse genome contains a single Herc2 locus, located in the jdf2 interval (juvenile development and fertility-2) on chromosome 7C. We have identified single nucleotide binding mutations in Herc2 in three alleles of N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea-induced jdf2 mutants, each in order to omit premature translation and / or deletion of conserved amino acids. Thus, mutations in Herc2 lead to the neuromuscular secretory vesicle and acrosome sperm defects, other developmental abnormalities, and juvenile lethality in jdf2 mice. Combined, these findings suggest that HERC2 is an important gene that encodes an GEF involved in protein trafficking and cell degradation pathways.

text: A woman with autosomal dominant preauricular fossa syndrome, cervical fistula, and partial deafness gave birth to two children with preauricular fossae and severe renal dysgenesis. The facies had some characteristics of the pottery facies of renal agenesis. One child died shortly after birth from pneumothorax and immature development of the lungs. We suggest that all infants with renal agenesis or dysgenesis be screened for preauricular fossa due to the high risk of recurrence of renal abnormalities in families with this syndrome.
